topoptlab.compliance_minimization moduleÔÉÅ

topoptlab.compliance_minimization.main(nelx, nely, volfrac, penal, rmin, ft, simulation_kw={'element order': 1, 'grid': 'regular', 'meshfile': None}, nelz=None, filter_mode='matrix', lin_solver='scipy-direct', preconditioner=None, assembly_mode='full', materials_kw={'E': 1.0}, body_forces_kw={}, bcs=<function mbb_2d>, lk=None, l=1.0, obj_func=<function compliance>, obj_kw={}, el_flags=None, optimizer='oc', optimizer_kw=None, mix=None, accelerator_kw={'accel_freq': 4, 'accel_start': 20, 'accelerator': None, 'max_history': 0}, nouteriter=2000, ninneriter=15, file='topopt', display=True, export=True, write_log=True, debug=0)[source]ÔÉÅ

Topology optimization workflow with the SIMP method based on the default direct solver of scipy sparse. Can treat single physics problems.

Parameters:

  • nelx (int) ‚Äì number of elements in x direction.

  • nely (int) ‚Äì number of elements in y direction.

  • volfrac (float) ‚Äì volume fraction.

  • penal (float) ‚Äì penalty exponent for the SIMP method.

  • rmin (float) ‚Äì cutoff radius for the filter. Only elements within the element-center to element center distance are used for filtering.

  • ft (int) ‚Äì integer flag for the filter. 0 sensitivity filtering, 1 density filtering, -1 no filter.

  • nelz (int or None) ‚Äì number of elements in z direction. If None, simulation is 2d.

  • filter_mode (str) ‚Äì indicates how filtering is done. Possible values are ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù or ‚Äúhelmholtz‚Äù. If ‚Äúmatrix‚Äù, then density/sensitivity filters are implemented via a sparse matrix and applied by multiplying said matrix with the densities/sensitivities.

  • solver (str) ‚Äì solver for linear systems. Check function lin solve for available options.

  • preconditioner (str or None) ‚Äì preconditioner for linear systems.

  • assembly_mode (str) ‚Äì whether full or only lower triangle of linear system / matrix is created.

  • bcs (str or callable) ‚Äì returns the boundary conditions

  • lk (None or callable) ‚Äì element stiffness matrix

  • l (float or tuple of length (ndim) or np.ndarray of shape (ndim)) ‚Äì side lengths of each element

  • obj_func (callable) ‚Äì objective function. Should update the objective value, the rhs of the the adjoint problem (currently only for stationary lin. problems) and a flag indicating whether the objective is self adjoint.

  • obj_kw (dict) ‚Äì keywords needed for the objective function. E. g. for a compliant mechanism and maximization of the displacement it would be the indicator array for output nodes. Check the objective for the necessary entries.

  • el_flags (np.ndarray or None) ‚Äì array of flags/integers that switch behaviour of specific elements. Currently 1 marks the element as passive (zero at all times), while 2 marks it as active (1 at all time).

  • optimizer (str) ‚Äì solver options which are ‚Äúoc‚Äù, ‚Äúmma‚Äù and ‚Äúgcmma‚Äù for the optimality criteria method, the method of moving asymptotes and the globally covergent method of moving asymptotes.

  • optimizer_kw (dict) ‚Äì dictionary with parameters for optimizer.

  • mix (None or float,) ‚Äì mixing parameter for design variable update.

  • nouteriter (int) ‚Äì number of TO iterations

  • ninneriter (int) ‚Äì number of inner iterations for GCMMA

  • display (bool) ‚Äì if True, plot design evolution to screen

  • file (str) ‚Äì name of output files

  • export (bool) ‚Äì if True, export design as vtk file.

  • write_log (bool) ‚Äì if True, write a log file and display results to command line.

  • debug (bool) ‚Äì if True, print extra output for debugging.

Return type:

None.
